Class Remove_Nth_Node_Back_From_List

java.lang.Object
Remove_Nth_Node_Back_From_List
public class Remove_Nth_Node_Back_From_List extends Object
LeetCode 19: Remove Nth Node From End of List

Problem Description:
Given the head of a linked list, remove the nth node from the end of the list and return its head.

Sample Input / Output: 


 Example 1:
 Input:  head = [1,2,3,4,5], n = 2
 Output: [1,2,3,5]

 Example 2:
 Input:  head = [1], n = 1
 Output: []

 Example 3:
 Input:  head = [1,2], n = 1
 Output: [1]

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the list is sz.
  • 1 invalid input: '<'= sz invalid input: '<'= 10^5
  • 0 invalid input: '<'= Node.val invalid input: '<'= 100
  • 1 invalid input: '<'= n invalid input: '<'= sz

  • Method Details

    • removeNthFromEndCounting

      public ListNode removeNthFromEndCounting(ListNode head, int n)
      Removes the nth node from the end by first counting the total length, then deleting the (length - n)th node from the front.

      Approach 1: Counting Method (Two Passes)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Count the length of the list:
        • Initialize length = 0 and a pointer curr = head.
        • Traverse the entire list while incrementing length.
        • Invariant: After traversal, length stores total nodes.
      2. Find the node before the target:
        • Target index from the front = length - n (0-based).
        • Create dummy node pointing to head to simplify head deletion.
        • Set curr = dummy.
        • Move forward length - n steps → curr now points to the node before the one to remove.
      3. Delete the target node:
        • Unlink it by curr.next = curr.next.next.
      4. Return result:
        • Return dummy.next as the new head.
      5. Edge Cases:
        • If n == length, it means remove head → handled by dummy node.
        • If list has only one node and n == 1, result is null.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — one pass to count, one pass to remove.
      • Space: O(1) — only pointers and counters used.

    • removeNthFromEndTwoPointers

      public ListNode removeNthFromEndTwoPointers(ListNode head, int n)
      Removes the nth node from the end using two pointers with a gap of n between them in one pass.

      Approach 2: Two Pointers (Fast invalid input: '&' Slow)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Create dummy node:
        • dummy = new ListNode(0, head) to simplify edge cases.
        • Initialize two pointers: fast = dummy, slow = dummy.
      2. Advance fast pointer by n+1 steps:
        • Move fast ahead n+1 times.
        • Reason: Creates a gap of n nodes between fast and slow.
        • After this, when fast reaches the end, slow will be just before the node to remove.
      3. Move both pointers together:
        • While fast != null, move both fast and slow forward one step at a time.
        • Invariant: Distance between fast and slow remains n.
      4. Delete the target node:
        • Now slow.next is the node to remove.
        • Perform slow.next = slow.next.next.
      5. Return result:
        • Return dummy.next as the updated head.
      6. Edge Cases:
        • If n == length, fast moves beyond head and slow stays at dummy, deleting head.
        • If only one node, deletion works since dummy bypasses it → returns null.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — each node visited once.
      • Space: O(1) — constant extra pointers used.
